string.name: intro_answer
string.ul:
•
For the past 2 months and a half, I have been given the opportunity to be a part of the POS team and get a first look at our the new system for Taco Bell.
 
•
I have had the opportunity to learn about Android, Git, Kotlin and much more!
 
•
I want to introduce and teach you all quickly about all the things Ive learned so far.

string.name: self_intro_answer
string.ul:
•
I attend the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

I will be going into my senior year, graduating Fall 2022.
 
•
I study computer Engineering and Computer Science.
 
•
I live in Chicago!
 
•
I love to go the gym, play on a Esports Team for a video game called Valorant and love to play guitar here and there!

string.name: android_a_one
string.ul:
•
An operation system that lets a device and an end user to be able to interact with one another.
 
•
In case you did not know, an operating system is computer software that works to integrate hardware and software resources.

resources.string: What can we build with android?

string.name: android_a_two
string.ul:
•
Billions of devices around the world are being powered by the Android OS, from smartphones, watches, tablets and more!
 
•
In more structured environments, you are able to utilize these devices and create something such as our POS which I will get into later.

resources.string: How to get started on android!

string.name: android_a_three
string.ul:
•
You can get started on using the Android OS by installing Android Studio, an IDE that allows you to languages such as Kotlin and Java to code and use android.
 
•
Developer.android.com has many resources to begin!

string.name: kotlin_a_one
string.ul:
•
Kotlin is a statically typed programming language that started its development in 2010.
 
•
In 2017, Kotlin was announced to be an official language for Android! 
•
Since Kotlin boils down and compiles to the same JVM bytecode as Java, Kotlin and Java are easily interchangeable and allow for each language to interact with other!

resources.string: Is there any prior experience needed for Kotlin?

string.name: kotlin_a_two
string.ul:
•
If you are a Java developer, you are in for a joy ride!
 
•
There are various resources to learn Kotlin, no prior experience necessary just as learning any new language.

resources.string: How can I get started on Kotlin?

string.name: kotlin_a_three
string.ul:
•
Thankfully, Kotlins developers have been so kind in providing various resources in starting!
 
•
There is also an article for the lazy Java developer byRenaud Cerrato.

string.name: xml_a_one
string.ul:
•
XML stands for eXtensible Markup Language
 
•
Allows you to describe data, in the case of Android, layouts, views, values, strings and colors!

resources.string: Where does XML come into play for Android?

string.name: xml_a_two
string.ul:
•
As mentioned above, XML allows us to create layouts for Android, a sort of UI interface!
 
•
There are various resources to learn XML, no prior experience necessary just as learning any new language.

resources.string: How can I get started on learning XML?

string.name: xml_a_three
string.ul:
•
Specifically for Android learning, XML can be learned from various sources, one being LinkedIn!
 
•
Androids website also includes many videos and guides for the introduction to using XML for Android layouts!

string.name: binding_a_one
string.ul:
•
For some context, Android allows the user to interact between Kotlin or Java code and XML.
 
•
Before, developers used Kotlin synthetics and the Butterknife library for Java, now we have View Binding!

string.name: binding_a_two
string.ul:
\n•
View Binding allows for easier code to be written for interaction between views.\n \n•
Allows for safer way to reference XML layout views.\n
For example in Kotlin synthetics, if you had 2 views named the same from 2 separate layout files, it would be difficult for the program to differentiate them.
In View Binding it creates a way for you to utilize the correct view being used. The binding object created allows you to reference the view that is tied with that layout file.

resources.string: How can I get started on implementing it correctly?

string.name: binding_a_three
git_a_one
string.ul:
\n•
Git is a software that allows for tracking of changes in any sets of files, usually used to collaborate among other software developers.\n

string.name: git_a_two
string.ul:
•
You have possibly heard of a repo which is short of repository.!
 
•
There are 2 types of repos, one being the remote repo. 
•
The remote repo is where code is stored on a code hosting service, Yum uses Gitlab or you may have also heard of Github! 
•
The local repo is where you have a copy of the remote repo locally on your machine, any changes made in the local repo will not affect the remote one.

resources.string: How do the remote and local repo interact?

string.name: git_a_three
string.ul:
•
To save any changes made on your local repo, you need to first commit your changes locally.
 
•
To then save those changes onto the remote repo, you need to push your changes, which will save changes to the remote repo.

resources.string: What other terms are there in Git?

string.name: git_a_four
string.ul:
•
In Git, we also have branches and developing in branches and the interaction between branches, such as merging a branch, pulling a branch or rebasing
 
•
For the sake of time, we wont go over it, but will link a confluence power point made by my mentor, Erica, which explains everything in detail!

string.name: jira_a_one
string.ul:
•
Jira is a tool that helps teams work together in a collaborative environment such as agile development.
 
•
Jira allows you to track tickets and issues, create roadmaps, and integrate many development tools!
 
•
More specifically, we can have tickets for features and bugfixes with information such as the ticket status, who created/reported the issues, how long we expect the ticket to take, etc.

string.name: jira_a_two
string.ul:
•
Agile development is a framework in which developers will practice that allows them to work in an environment to solve solutions in the form of sprints!
 
•
For Poseidon, we work in weeks of 3, which is a time frame where we get an amount of work done by the next sprint.

string.name: mvvm_a_one
string.ul:
•
There are multiple ways in which we can structure our code, some that have been put in place and developed over time.
 
•
Some common architecture patterns in software development are Model-View-Controller(MVC), Model-View-Presenter(MVP), Model-View-ViewModel(MVVM), and Model-View-Intent(MVI).

resources.string: Poseidons use of MVM and MVVM, what are models and views?

string.name: mvvm_a_two
string.ul:
•
A model is a layer of data or information of the software.
 
•
A view is a class that displays visual elements on the screen.
 
•
MVP is where we have a Presenter be able to communicate with a model and a view, however, the model and view. The presenter is a bridge that handles communication of what can get displayed on the screen.
 
•
MVVM is where the model and view have the same responsibilities as described above, now we have a ViewModel that is the brains and the logic of the interface.

string.name: pos_a_one
string.ul:
\n•
A point-of-sale is a system that allows the merchant to collect information to complete a transaction based on what was asked/purchased of the customer.\n

resources.string: Poseidons creation of a new POS

string.name: pos_a_two
string.ul:
•
For now, our focus has been Taco Bell to convert their Xenial system to a new system that allows an easier experience for the service champion, the employees taking customer orders.
 
•
We are making this new one because it would create easier experiences for the service champion, easy to deploy on Android tablets, and we would not have to then rely on outside companies to supply our POS systems.

resources.string: Will we create the same sort of POS for other brands?

string.name: pos_a_three
string.ul:
•
To be able to eventually launch this POS to other brands, we want to keep some implementations the same while also being flexible in what the other brand would want for customization.
 
•
We would want to keep menu, payment, employee services and others to be flexible across brands.
 
•
We would then be able to create brand specific modules that is easily implemented with Yums shared modules.
